docs.lead_paragraph: YOU can see them coming, little sets of shadows connected by thin black leashes, slicing their way through the haze of dawn. It's 6 A.M., and the daylong stream of dog people who make up the community at George's Run in Washington Square Park has begun. The early morning professionals attend to their dogs' business, bide the time with quick cigarettes and coffee and then rush home. Next comes the midmorning mix of mothers with strollers, artists and the work-at-home crowd, a group for whom "How's your baby?" might refer to an infant, a puppy or the Great American Novel. Then the run fills with retirees like Martin Becker, who sits with his dog, Toto, and mutters the story of their meeting: "I was only supposed to watch him one night, and that was eight years ago!" The dog walkers -- a clique burdened with jangling sets of other people's keys and leashes -- keep the older folks company and complain about bosses and endless flights of stairs.
